0743442539|5.0|I heard this book touted at a writer's conference as the best spy novel ever written--so naturally, being the bookworm I am, I bought it. Three chapters in, I was fascinated, but rediculously confused. But I continued reading, because while I had no idea what was going on, I could tell that it was obviously sleight of hand by the author and not lack of skill.     This isn't the most accessible novel or even easy to understand, but it is definitely good, and at times, flat out brilliant as the layers of the plot get thicker and thicker and the intensity ratchets higher and higher. It is also worth mentioning that I would not usually expect a book like this to have the heart that it does--I found simple love story between Leamas and Liz quite beautiful, and the the strong, forceful ideas of the next to last chapter chillingly satisfying.
B00005O3VC|5.0|King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table set out on a quest to find the Holy Grail...as told to do so by a cartoon God that lives in the clouds...<br /><br />Easily the most hilarious and original comedy ever made, Monty Python and the Holy Grail claims it's undisputed throne through insanely ridiculous situations and characters that will very likely never be duplicated. Pure comedic genius that doesn't go stale with age or decades of competition having been released. Simply seeing the way comedy films are made today, this film will very likely have a long reign before anything can even hold a candle to it. An absolute belly-laugh fest that never lets up.<br /><br />Only the cast of Monty Python could have pulled this film off, with each actor playing many different characters...all hilarious! The genius in the actors' lines themselves are truly to be admired. The comedic style of talking in circles is one technique that most comedies do not try to do, simply because they can't compete with the genius of this film, which uses it flawlessly. Those that do try usually fall flat on their faces. Two particularly excellent examples of this can be seen in the beginning scene, in which the characters discuss the origins of coconuts.....and the other when Lancelot breaks into the swamp castle to save the \\"damsel in distress.\\" This is merely one technique that the cast has perfected to conjure up laughs consistently throughout the entire film. The only way that I can imagine that someone might not like this film is if they simply do not enjoy it's type of humor. Too bad for them.<br /><br />Another hilarious technique used in the film is the use of comedy in the background. From people slamming cats against poles for no apparent reason, to people filling up baskets with mud in the fields....all very strange and hilarious at the same time. It's also simply amazing that all of the characters are played by the same group of actors, which shows the great range all of them have. Some are simply unrecognizable from one character to the other and it sometimes takes a good eye to pick them out, which makes it fun. And I don't want to ruin it for anyone, but this film takes some turns that no sane person could see coming.<br /><br />Ridiculous characters in ridiculous situations equals ridiculous laughter.<br /><br />The epitome of all-star comedy that will no doubt continue to stand the test of time. B000GFLAI0|5.0|This is going to be a different type of review, but, I believe, an honest one. The reason my review is a little dated is because my brother gave me this album on Thursday, November, 16, 2006. He said you've got to listen to this. It's great. Well, I was very hesitant in listening to it. You see, I had written Bob Dylan off back in the early '90's after I had seen him perform on a few shows on TV. I couldn't understand a thing he said, and the melodies sounded like junk. Bob's voice sounded like he had mush in his mouth, and he sounded like he was down in some dungeon. I was totally embarassed for him, and embarassed when old friends of mine approached me after seeing the same performances and riding me about why they could never see what I had seen in Dylan for years. <br /> <br />You see, I was a Bob Dylan fan from the beginning, way back in the Folk days of the sixties. I went through the Electric period when alot of Dylan fanatics turned on him, but I didn't. I went through his Spiritual years, also when many Dylan fans turned away from him and I stuck in there. But, after hearing how bad he was in his performing in the early to mid '90's, even I gave up. Now, my brother lays this \\"Modern Times\\" album on me. I put it in my CD player, expecting the mush I had last heard. Remember, I hadn't heard \\"Time Out Of Mind\\", or \\"Love and Theft\\" at all. When I had heard that he won awards for these two albums my reaction was one of disbelief, and didn't care to give them a try. When \\"Modern Times\\" started playing I couldn't believe my ears. This is the old Dylan, sort of. Sure, his voice was more gravelly, but I could understand him, and the band was excellent. A few songs like \\"Thunder On The Mountain\\", Spirit On The Water\\", When The Deal Goes Down\\", Nettie Moore\\", The Levee's Gonna Break\\", and \\"Ain't Talkin'\\", were pure Bob Dylan, with a blues twist to them. You know Folk always was just a step away from The Blues, all along. The songs like \\"Someday Baby\\" and \\"Beyond The Horizon\\"  are basically mainstream country-rock, easy listening, but with Bob Dylan's distinct style. Sinatra could have done \\"Someday Baby\\". <br /> <br />For me, Bob Dylan was back! Something I never thought would happen. What a great surprise! I have been wondering for a long while why two of my all-time \\"Real Country\\" heroes, Merle Haggard and Willie Nelson, had wanted to tour with Dylan. My gosh, do they want to turn their fans off? And, for what reason. <br /> <br />Well, as I'm sitting here, I can't wait, from what I've heard from other reviewers, to here \\"Time Out Of Mind\\" and \\"Love and Theft\\". Before hearing \\"Modern Times\\" I certainly wasn't going to be crazy enough to waste my money on the other two albums. Now, I am crazy enough to spend my money on the previous two. But, I don't think it's going to be a waste. I can't wait!

B000ICL3KG|5.0|I was sceptical. Cyclical climate change is and always has been universal. So what's new? The rate of change is new, unnatural and, if unchecked, catastrophic - the inescapable conclusion of Gore's thoroughly researched, honest and well documented argument. I was surprised by the force of the film without hysteria, rancour, spin or special effects. Consistent with the UK Stern Report, Gore shows the cost of reversing climate change to be negligible compared with the cost of neglecting it. The means to fix it are here and now. What are we waiting for? We're waiting for a critical mass of us who drive ourselves to our own fates, together with those who drive others, nations and corporations, to ease off the accelerator and apply the brake. B00005JPCA|5.0|While many I knew thought that a blond guy couldn't possibly pull off Bond, I had seen Layer Cake and was pretty sure that Craig was capable of much.  What I didn't expect, was a screenplay so well written and updated that comparisons to recent Bond films would seem an insult.  Detailed breakdown as follows: <br /> <br />Acting:  While everybody does a great job, Daniel Craig and Eva Green are quite fantastic.  Green is appropriately playful and serious when the role requires it.  She gets many of the movie's best lines.  Your opinion of Craig's performance will come down to how well you understand what's being done to the character over the course of the movie.  Given that you do, Craig's performance is masterful.  I can't say more without spoiling something. <br /> <br />Score: Arnold's score feels VERY traditional.  I couldn't distinguish the main Bond theme in the end credits from its counterpart in early Bond movies.  This is good, though- it makes the movie feel connected to its early predecessors.  There are also some achingly beautful but short cues associated with scene changes where the camera pans over long highways, etc. <br /> <br />Effects: For a number of reasons, the effects are not the main attraction here.  However, when they are called for, they are pretty spectacular.  This isn't the gadget-driven Bond of recent years, but technology is rather seamlessly integrated into the film. <br /> <br />Plot: I've slowly learned that you don't go into Bond movies (and more generally, action movies) looking to be impressed by plot.  There's a certain plot structure that you know will be observed.  In this Bond, I didn't know most of the time where the plot was headed.  This aspect, alone, left me glued to the screen.  Casino Royale is, of course, based on the first Bond novel of the same name.  The powers that be decided to update the story and essentially restart the character a la Batman Begins.  What really struck me was how skillfully modern references were added in to make the story relevant and believable.  It doesn't seem too farfetched that the bare-bones of the plot could happen today.  In more ways than I can say here, this is not a traditional Bond film.  Approach it in that frame of mind and you'll be blown away.

0446310786|4.0|TKaM is not the finest piece of prose -- though it does have some terrific (sometimes humorous, sometimes heartbreaking) stretches.  Nor is it the most compelling story.  But it is a story well told, well voiced (by its very young narrator), and well paced.  Above all, it is a story whose themes -- addressed to the best and the worst in human nature -- endure, themes that (one alternately hopes and is greatly saddened to think) will endure forever.  For this reason, in spite of its quaint anachronistic feel, TKaM is a novel for the ages, and a particularly important read for children.  I had the special pleasure of listening to TKaM narrated by Sissy Spacek, the perfect voice for Scout.

0670033375|3.0|The author, Diamond, has impeccable credentials.  Several of his scientific works, especially his 1975 collection which he edited, Ecology and evolution of Communities, are classics in the various fields in which he has worked.  His last work, Guns, Germs and Steel, earned him a Pulitzer, so you know he is well-regarded.<br /><br />In Collapse, Diamond surveys several carefully chosen civilizations where environmental impact of humans possibly led to their demise.  He starts with an overview of current-day Montana, and then covers Easter Island, Pitcairn Island, Henderson Island, Pueblo Indians of the Southwestern US, some of the Mayans, and Greenlanders.  He then covers a few success stories like New Guinea, Tikopia (pacific island), and Japan.<br /><br />Next he covers a few modern collapses like Rwanda, Haiti, China and Australia.  Lastly are a few chapters on practical lessons.<br /><br />The book starts slowly with descriptions of Montana ranches and communities and the changes in this area.  The pace and intensity of the writing pick up when Diamond speculates on Easter Island and its demise.  Diamond speculates on causes of the changes in Easter Island and its ecology.  Since he uses Easter Island as a \\"metaphor\\" for civilization and environmental degradation, this section of the book is vital.  Turns out that the story may well be different than Diamond knew.  See an article by Hunt in the New Scientist for the latest thoughts.  It seems that man's inhumanity to man may have been the main culprit in the sad story of the Easter Islanders.  Slavery and smallpox probably led to the demise of islander's more than their deforesting the island.  Nevertheless, the Easter Islanders did manage to deforest their land rather quickly.  There are still lessons to be drawn, but just not as clear-cut (play on words) as Diamond postulates.<br /><br />Another main part of Diamond's thesis concerns Greenland.  If you will read other sources, you will see that Diamond again over-speculates and leaves out important data.  The paucity of data on what happened to the last Greenlanders supports the idea that they simply packed up and left when the climate cooled too much for self-sufficiency.  Not nearly as spectacular an end as starving to death or being wiped out by the eskimos.<br /><br />The best parts of this book are, in my opinion, the parts where Diamond speculates on lost cultures.  You may not agree on all Diamond says, (nor do many professional scientists of various kinds) but at least Diamond gives us something to think about, and backs up his views with supporting studies.<br /><br />But in order to use these few examples as a metaphor for modern, global civilization, the examples should be more accurate and more comprehensive.  What about Asia, African and Europe?  In the end many, if not  most, of past civilizations died from war and politics.  If anything, Diamonds examples are warnings against big government and immorality.<br /><br />The weakest part of the book are the practical lessons.  Diamond, for example uses the Cuban missile crisis as a paradigm of how government can learn from past mistakes.  According to Diamond, Kennedy learned from the Bay of Pigs fiasco and then handled the missile crisis correctly.  Again, although institutions can learn from past mistakes, this particular example is exactly the opposite.  As I learned from Military War college printed and oral information, Kennedy completely misread the Russians and his poor handling of the Bay of Pigs is what led to the missle crisis.  He then surrendered completely, giving up our forward bases in Turkey and promising to let mass-murderer Castro alone.  And this is just one example of how poltical bias leads to biased conclusions.  Famine seems to almost always be cause by government policy, for example.  I recommend reading PJ O'Rourke's writings for a different take on Somalia, Bengladesh and the like.<br /><br />Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this book.  Its subject matter is interesting and well presented.  The conclusions are however suspect due to some bias on the part of the author.njoyed this book.  Its subject matter is interesting and well presented.  The conclusions are however suspect due to some bias on the part of the author.
B00005JPCA|5.0|Despite significant changes to the Bond film formula, the world's most famous spy is surprisingly better than ever. Is this a James Bond movie, or a legitimate spy film? If you're not a fan of the old Bond films because the franchise had lost touch with reality, then let Casino Royale reintroduce you to the world's greatest spy.<br /><br />Some might not like the departure from some elements of the previous 20 Bond films, but I say that's what makes Casino Royale stand apart, and it's exactly why this film will soon be regarded as the best Bond film ever made. There are no scientifically impossible gadgets or physics (\\"Q\\" doesn't even make an appearance) and no ridiculous doomsday plots (he's not saving the world, just proving himself). There are no brainless beauties just for the sake of being eyecandy (though Eva Green is absolutely beautiful as Vesper Lynd).<br /><br />But what of Daniel Craig? If you base your critique of an actor's performance as Bond on how well he compares to the character in the pages of Ian Fleming's novels, then this James Bond is the best in his bigscreen history. Sean Connery was an entertaining Bond, but he was never this good at being Bond. Maybe it's because the James Bond franchise is no longer a \\"relic of the Cold War\\" (as M refered to Bond in Goldeneye), but a modern film franchise that intends to be taken seriously in the 21st century. And after watching Daniel Craig in Casino Royale, I'm taking James Bond seriously for the first time in my life.<br /><br />This Bond actually appears worthy of 00 status. He is equal parts bold and brash. He's extraordinarily talented and resolute. Most importantly, he's human. He has personality. In Casino Royale, James Bond isn't the same man from the beginning to the end. We watch him change. For the first time ever when watching a Bond film, I felt involved with the plot.<br /><br />This time, the film means something. It's not just mindless entertainment, but excellent cinema. Pick this one up!s one up!

She continues in the movie to search for more answers to questions that were brought about in the first Underworld.   Quite frankly, I thought this was a better movie than the first.  The story was more clear and easier to follow, but surprisingly complex and full of characters who weren't falling into a sterotype.  As Selene and the Werewolf/Vampire Hybrid, Michael (Scott Speedman) rush to make sure that Marcus (one of the oldest and most powerful of warriors, and a hybrid himself) doesn't free his brother William (the first of the Lycans). After Kraven releases him, he searches for the key to unlock his brothers prison.  A lot of things from the first movie start to play a part in this movie as we find out more about Selene's mortal family and the role they play in this.  We find out more about the oldest immortal, William and Marcus' father, who refuses to kill his own sons.  The story becomes more dangerous and more insidious as it moves to the climax.  Blood and gore abound in this movie, giving it the well deserved R rating, but it's actually confined to the fight scenes and does not seem out of place for the type of fighting that's going on. <br /> <br />Overall, the movie was better than expected.  It had a brisk pace, a good story and dialogue as well as great action sequences and impressive special affects.

The beasts aren't stop motion....They're real! For the filming of these flicks they actually cloned dinosaurs from dino DNA preserved in prehistoric amber! Alright, alright...they look real. Very real. The FX are brilliant in all three Jurassic Parks. I tore through it because it was so good. B00005JPCA|4.0|James Bond has always been a shallow figure, so super suave and so heavily stylized, yet completely lacking in substance. At last, we have a film that gives Agent 007 some depth and complexity; it's called \\"Casino Royale,\\" and while it isn't a perfect film, it's still a far cry from some of the overly ambitious early attempts in the franchise. It's an action film, yet the story isn't drowned out in wall-to-wall stunts. It's a mystery, yet the twists and turns aren't piled on top of each other. It's even a love story, yet it isn't sappy or melodramatic. This is the James Bond movie I've been waiting for: a pleasing blend of classic intrigue, danger, suspense, and sexuality in a plot that--true to the Spy Film genre--isn't even remotely plausible. What a fun, fun movie this was.    This is the first Bond film in many years that's actually based on an Ian Fleming novel. I can't say whether or not that made it worth seeing; I've never read anything he's written, and I can't compare them to the other twenty Bond films. But I can say that this story hit all the right notes, both as an action film and as a character analysis. I could describe in detail what the film is about, but does it really matter? All you need to know is that it's a prequel, and it covers Bond's very first mission. The long and short of it is that he has to prevent a banker from winning at a casino tournament in Montenagro; the prize money will only go towards funding terrorist activities. Specifically what activities are never alluded to, but that's irrelevant. We all know that terrorism, in any form, should be stopped.    Early on in the film, Bond says, \\"I understand double-ohs have a very short life expectancy.\\" How true: the character is now played by Daniel Craig, the sixth actor to assume the role (following a long and fairly mediocre run with Pierce Brosnan). This new portrayal gives Bond a different dimension, one that helps to define him more as a person and less as a debonair drone. Craig definitely gives him a suave demeanor, and to say he isn't physically attractive would be a bold-faced lie. Yet there's an underlying ruggedness to this new James Bond, one that replaces some of the more pristine Bonds of the past. His face shows some wear, as if to say that he's seen plenty of action. He's even capable of making mistakes, as seen during the casino tournament when he incorrectly assumes the tactics of his opponent.    Noticeably absent from \\"Casino Royale\\" are the wealth of over the top gadgets and gizmos; the best we're given are a couple of guns and a few miscellaneous items in the glove compartment of a sports car (including a defibrillator, which will eventually come in handy). I liked this; for once, Bond will have to use his wits and physical strength as opposed to ridiculous science fiction-grade props to gain the upper hand. There are no watches with built in lasers or pens that fire tiny darts. There's no eject button for his car's driver's side seat. There's no hidden radio in his cufflinks. Of course, such a change also required the absence of Q (first played by Desmond Llewelyn, then played by John Cleese). He could always be counted on for a bit of comedy relief.    But I see this as a good thing; this time around, comedy relief wasn't needed. Small doses of appropriately timed humor were scattered all throughout the film, and not just from one character. It was an especially welcome change for Judi Dench to be given a couple funny lines; M was always such a serious character, and she definitely needed to lighten up. In \\"Casino Royale,\\" she's initially portrayed as being very hesitant around Bond, especially since his ego caused him to mess up a few very important missions. He even breaks into her apartment, not to steal anything, but simply to speak to her face to face. She finds such an act untrustworthy, and she's understandably worried about his success at the casino tournament.    Interestingly enough, those moments in the casino are the best the film has to offer, despite being relatively quiet and low key. Bond plays against Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), the film's lead villain. Despite the fact that he says and does little, he's probably one of the coldest villains ever seen in a Bond film. He sits across from 007 with an expression that you'd swear would turn you to stone (if it weren't for the fact that his left eye has an injured tear duct, resulting in tears of blood). He fiddles with his poker chips intensely yet carefully. He makes grandiose bets that he knows Bond will attempt to outdo. There's calculation going through this man's mind, and it was fascinating to watch him at that table (it was also fascinating to watch him during an especially uncomfortable torture scene). If it weren't for the fact that he doesn't fit the usual profile of a Bond villain, that he doesn't have a secret lair rigged with electronic booby traps, and that he doesn't have an exotic pet, then I'd say he would appeal to those looking for a classic bad guy.    And then there's Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), an accoutant and the inevitable love interest. She and Bond play off each other perfectly, with one initially finding the other's personality flaws irritating. Yet there's a definite attraction, made stronger by the mission they're to complete together. She eventually awakens within Bond a desire, one that allows him to see her as a person as opposed to a sexual object (and we all know that James Bond is notoriously sexual). After a while, she, too, beings to see him in a different light. At that point, we can't help but wonder what would happen if the world's greatest secret agent were to settle down, marry, and possibly have a family. Can anyone picture such a circumstance? Of course they can't; James Bond is a man of action, dedicated to service but attached to no one.    This is the kind of complexity I've always wanted to see, and I'm glad the filmmakers of \\"Casino Royale\\" decided to make use of it. I'm alsoglad that it was balanced with a couple of good action sequences; yes, each one is over the top and completely unrealistic, but they're so entertaining that the little details aren't even noticed. Of course no one can jump off of a hundred-foot crane and live to tell the tale. Of course you can't shoot at someone while leaping in mid air. Of course such bodily harm would result in debilitating injuries. No one thought about such things while watching the other James Bond movies, so why start now? This is a worthy addition to the 007 franchise; I can only hope that future additions will be as good.
B0000AQS0F|5.0|I was only recently alerted to this show, and watched it all in the span of two nights, and that includes the movie.  It has restored much of my interest in TV sci-fi that was lost in the mid- to late 90s.
B000K7VHQ4|5.0|Edward Norton gave an amazing, unforgettable performance in this film. As did Jessica Biel and Paul Giamatti. 0307346609|5.0|With his new book Max Brooks creates a realistic near future with our world ravaged by the walking dead. WORLD WAR Z, from start to finish, is presented as an UN commissioned oral history, consisting of a series of interviews with various survivors of the zombie plague virus which originated somewhere in China, swept the world and nearly killed off humankind. We not only hear from the politicians, scientists and soldiers of what became a bizarre world war; we also get some insight as to how the average (and a few not so average) held out and helped to beat back the overwhelming numbers of ghouls who were soon literally clawing at every wall and door. It's not only the physically strong, quick witted and well-armed who survived but also some of those that we would naturally consider to be easy pickings for the zombie: the complacent and sheltered suburban housewife, the timid and sensitive little man, the nerdy tech geek, the hadicapped, and even those young children and cute and cuddly housepets who were lost or abandoned in the the confusion and terror during the early days of the plague's spread. Brooks does good work showing what they were forced to do and what they became as they adapted to this new world. For example, the interview with the Japanese blind man and his sidekick, the formerly socially detached internet addict, was excellently done and made one of the best stories in the book. Another great tale was the one told by a mercenary who was hired to guard a celebrity hideaway/compound. The fate of that place was told with a humorous cynicism and a culmination of poetic justice that can only be read as a sad satire on today's cultural wasteland (you will also easily guess who are the real-life people characterized in this particular story).<br /><br />The zombie isn't our only enemy in this infected world. From the interviews we read about ecological disasters, the return of old diseases and the beginnings of new psychological disorders. We hear of people who saw the plague as an outlet for their particular hatreds and perversities, and of others who saw in it an opportunity to declaring themselves kings of their own little dungheaps. Zombies may have rendered many oldstyle religious and political fanaticisms obsolete, only to help create new ones. The world after the plague is a place where some of the old world powers disintegrated in impotence amidst chaos, while others have arisen in the most unlikely places. It is a time of new and strange alliances, with overwhelming numbers of refugees, many of them the migrations of entire national populations, it is a place of sinister phenomena with disturbing mysteries (e.g. the fate of the North Koreans). Meanwhile, the war continues. As many of the survivors fled to the cold northern parts of the globe, so did the ghouls. Despite the constant vigilance of the allied UN forces, with each spring thaw the zombie continues to rise and to kill.<br /><br />Now I would also like to say a few things about the comments made by some reviewers here on the political opinions of Max Brooks:<br />I do not understand their anger, nor do I respect their spite. Brooks created a fictional world as he sees it and he pulls it off. He is never in the reader's face with his politics and he never resorts to preaching those politics. Instead he subtly allows his views to shape and mold his book as all other authors do. Whatever he might think of the present American political situation, the Iraq War, the NRA, organized religion etc., he has written a genuinely intelligent and entertaining work of satire/commentary and horror/science fiction. One doesn't need to agree with all of his viewpoints in order to recognize that this is a good book and simply enjoy it. I for one wish that this book was longer and hope that he writes another volume of its kind.the plague as an outlet for their particular hatreds and perversities, and of others who saw in it an opportunity to declaring themselves kings of their own little dungheaps. Zombies may have rendered many oldstyle religious and political fanaticisms obsolete, only to help create new ones. The world after the plague is a place where some of the old world powers disintegrated in impotence amidst chaos, while others have arisen in the most unlikely places. It is a time of new and strange alliances, with overwhelming numbers of refugees, many of them the migrations of entire national populations, it is a place of sinister phenomena with disturbing mysteries (e.g. the fate of the North Koreans). Meanwhile, the war continues. As many of the survivors fled to the cold northern parts of the globe, so did the ghouls. Despite the constant vigilance of the allied UN forces, with each spring thaw the zombie continues to rise and to kill.      Now I would also like to say a few things about the comments made by some reviewers here on the political opinions of Max Brooks:  I do not understand their anger, nor do I respect their spite. Brooks created a fictional world as he sees it and he pulls it off. He is never in the reader's face with his politics and he never resorts to preaching those politics. Instead he subtly allows his views to shape and mold his book as all other authors do. Whatever he might think of the present American political situation, the Iraq War, the NRA, organized religion etc., he has written a genuinely intelligent and entertaining work of satire/commentary and horror/science fiction. One doesn't need to agree with all of his viewpoints in order to recognize that this is a good book and simply enjoy it. I for one wish that this book was longer and hope that he writes another volume of its kind.

0679720200|4.0|This short novel exemplifies existentialism. Life is meaningless and daily events are trivial. These points are emphasized through the main character, Meursault, and his dispassionate manner. His reaction towards the death of his mother is summed up with the indifferent statement of \\"Maman died today. Or yesterday maybe...\\" As incomprehensible as his response is, as a reader, I found myself sympathizing and relating to this emotionally isolated man.<br /><br /> The Stanger, though not a happy book, is a an insightful and interesting read. Recognizing unfortunate similarities between yourself and the character of Meursault is bound to take place (such as the need to observe surrounding human tendencies, or the need to guard yourself against disappointment). Though you will not be able to fully embrace the character Meursault, you cannot help but feel that his outlook on life makes perfect sense.<br /><br />  Albert Camus excels at using the various characters within The Stanger to represent allegories of life. With old Salamano and his dog, one witnesses the power of daily routine and the resistance to change. Camus' writing style is to the point and easy to read. I enjoyed the existential theme and loved attempting to dissect the complex character of Meursault.

B00005JPCA|5.0|There have been several reboots of the James Bond series but this one is by far the most dramatic and succesful. In `License to Kill' the producers decided to send Bond back to his roots with the grittiest, most realistic Bond movie ever. Unfortunately they produced arguably the worst official Bond movie ever. Besides `From Russia with Love', `Casino Royale' is perhaps the most faithful adaptation of a Bond novel. The first third of the movie sets up the story and the rest of the movie picks up where the book begins. There was a complete reworking of the ending to add excitement but it actually served to make things rather confusing.<br /><br />So is it a success? I am a lifelong Bond fan who owns nearly every Bond film on DVD and I would measure this film as one of the best ever. Like Batman Begins, this as a textbook example of how a venerable series can be reworked a correctly. Unlike many Bond fans I was pleased with the choice of Daniel Craig as the new Bond and he exceeded my best expectations. Gone are the asinine Bond one liners. Gone are the crazy gadgets and say farewell to Q and Moneypenny. The core of guns, gorgeous woman and opulent settings remain intact, in fact this may be the most beautiful Bond movie ever created. The only complaint I have is that the music wasn't up to par. For some reason the producers of this generation of Bond films don't seem to be able to capture the fantastic music accompaniments of films like Goldfinger, You Only Die Twice and even Moonraker.<br /><br />Die Another Day made piles of cash but the series was becoming increasingly painful. The absurd stunts, the headache inducing double entendres, the bad dialogue and the silly characters would have eventually done the series in. After Moonraker the producers pulled way back and released For Your Eyes Only. Personally I found Moonraker the more enjoyable of the two. Casino Royale is the best reboot yet and ranks as the best Bond since at least the Roger Moore era. The story is smaller, the characters more believable and the dialogue is VASTLY improved. Sorry Pierce but Daniel Craig is a big improvement. Good Job EON.smaller, the characters more believable and the dialogue is VASTLY improved. Sorry Pierce but Daniel Craig is a big improvement. B000K7VHPU|5.0|`The Illusionist' provides great, old-fashioned fun.  Much like `The Prestige,' it is a magician's movie that requires the audience to keep their eyes on the subject.  This time the titled `illusionist,' Eisenheim (Edward Norton) is at the top of his form, but instead of wanting fame and fortune like the magicians in `The Prestige,' he keeps his eyes on the duchess, the love interest of the Crown Prince Leopold (Rufus Sewell).  At one point his fame gets him invited to an affair held by the Crown Prince, himself, and Eisenheim provides a trick to pull up the Prince's sword, much like the child with the pure heart does in the medieval fable.  He succeeds, but not without some doubts.  His embarrassment at this awkward moment creates a rivalry with `the illusionist'.  Supported by the chief inspector (Paul Giamatti), Eisenheim has just enough time to conjure a brazen love affair with the duchess.  But a drunken confrontation between the Prince and his unfaithful fianc&eacute; provides tragedy, one that seems to only be answered by a different venue on the illusionist's stage.  The Prince's jealous rage has him figuratively putting a noose around Eisenheim, one from which he must escape.<br /><br />While `The Prestige' benefits from Christopher Nolan's modern direction with a progressively dark appeal, `The Illusionist' has time-honored filmmaking with appeal that delivers its magic with greater resolution (from director, Neil Burger).  Both movies are excellent and are edited with precision, but while `The Prestige' is masterful at development; `The Illusionist' wins in a matchup.
B00005JPCA|4.0|When Ian Fleming wrote him, James Bond was a tough-as-nails, take-no-prisoners spy.  Sean Connery played him that way in the beginning and never truely got away from it, but over the years, Bond got softened up and too chatty.  Pierce Brosnan offered up the excellent GOLDENEYE and followed that with three pretty good Bonds.<br /><br />But Daniel Craig is going to remake the franchise and bring it back more to Ian Fleming's original creation.  Craig's Bond is cold, calculating, and driven.  A hard, bloody job takes a harder, bloodthirsty man who brings everything to the bottom line no matter what the cost.  Craig even looks as rough-and-tumble as Connery did in the early movies.  He has a predator's body, heavily muscled and lean.  His eyes are those of a hunter.<br /><br />Daniel Craig has done a lot of different things, including being in a Tomb Raider movie and other action films, so he has quite a bit to bring to the picnic.  Also, at 38, he should be able to carry the role for a few movies.  Martin Campbell, the director, gave us Zorro with Antonio Banderas and Brosnan's first Bond film, GOLDENEYE.  Bond writers, Neal Purvis and Robert Wade (THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH and DIE ANOTHER DAY) return for this movie as well as the next, but Paul Haggis (CRASH, MILLION DOLLAR BABY, FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS) joins them.<br /><br />The plot in CASINO ROYALE shifts and evolves, begging a little patience from the audience but ultimately rewarding it.  The movie actually \\"feels\\" as though it's come to an ending three times, with mixed results, before finally cutting to credits.<br /><br />While in Madagascar, Bond -- newly risen to double-oh status in a dark, cold prologue -- is hunting a terrorist funding network.  Almost immediately, the film plunges into headlong action that takes advantage of PARKOUR, the free running style that's gotten so much attention in France.  These sequences are awesome, and even when you see them you'll have trouble believing them.  Of course, they're helped along by some CG work and stunt gear, but nevertheless, it's a romp that ends in a fiery shootout at an embassy.<br /><br />We get introduced to Le Chiffre, the terrorist banker that is Bond's true quarry, in a threatening scene that shows what he is up against and the threats he faces on a daily basis.  He has an oddity, as most Bond villains do, though his isn't of a homicidal nature.  He has mismatched eyes and one of them weeps blood.<br /><br />Bond picks up Le Chiffre's trail in the Bahamas, providing a nice scenic backdrop to action and beautiful women in swimwear.  His infiltration of the Ocean Club to get the information he needs is simple and direct, but with all the finesse of a sledgehammer at work.  This is Fleming's raw Bond at work that so many of the moviegoers haven't ever witnessed because they haven't read the books.<br /><br />THe action and plotting quickly adds layers of complexity, providing a great bit of storytelling that somehow even manages to make the protracted card game interesting even though it should have passed much more quickly. 0316172324|3.0|This is a book about the split decisions we make--our first impression, our gut reaction, our instinct--within the first two seconds of encountering a problem. Gladwell sets up in his introduction that we too often disregard that gut feeling and eventually over-think, over-analyze, and over-rationalize our decisions. Like in THE TIPPING POINT, Gladwell makes his point through varied and interesting case studies in unexpected fields of study. And although I found some of the case studies fascinating, I was under-whelmed by Gladwell's point overall. Maybe I expected the evidence for making snap judgments to be more compelling. From the title of the book, I expected Gladwell's point to be more about the advantages of snap decisions, but he also provides plenty of examples of when snap judgments can be disastrous. While this is all interesting, I was left feeling like Gladwell's point was a bit muddied. As opposed to a book FOR the advantages of that snap decisions, it seems like a book just about snap decisions, with the theme being that sometimes they are good and sometimes they are bad. Which, for all the interest of the case studies, is a fairly pedestrian thesis.

Needless to say, her attitude does a 180 degree turn as the movie unfolds. <br /> <br />There are many of the classic Bond accessories, including high tech gadgets and fancy roadsters.  But these serve as spice to liven up an already excellent story, not as the main dish in themselves.  Throw in international intrigue and some fantastic action sequences, and you have a refreshingly original film that stays true to the best of the series.  Very highly recommended.

B000HWZ4A2|5.0|King Vidor's hysterically overwrought 1949 film is finally available on DVD, and well worth a look. It's full of ludicrously didactic speeches (by Ayn Rand herself) and mismatched performances (Neal's \\"expressionist\\" performance - all angles and curves - v. Cooper's exhausted naturalism). It is not a forgotten masterpiece, as some have recently claimed, but it is endlessly fascinating. Rand attempts to appropriate Nietzsche (Roark = Nietzschean superman) and place him in an American context. Yet for all its celebration of individual initiative/integrity, and all its attacks on the masses and mob mentality, the film seems to want us to SUBMIT to the charisma and force of the male protagonist. How is this not unlike what the National Socialists attempted by claiming Nietzsche as a precursor to fascist ideology? Note, in particular, the final shot and its jaw-dropping symbolism: Roark astride the world's tallest skyscraper as the camera (simulating the POV of Dominique) slowly makes its ways towards his outstretched legs? You might think my write-up a bit exaggerated -- but wait until you see the film! My review is modest in comparison!!

B00005JPCA|5.0|I am a die-hard James Bond fan. I was absolutely devastated when I learned that Pierce Brosnan wouldn't be returning for a fifth installment as Bond and that blondie Daniel Craig was chosen as the replacement. I spent almost two years dreading \\"Casino Royale,\\" convinced that it would be absolutely horrible and that Craig's performance would be a disgrace to the character. Well, all that worrying was a waste of time on my part. When I'm wrong, I say I'm wrong, and I was very wrong about this.<br /><br />Here's the bottom line: \\"Casino Royale\\" is the best Bond movie ever...hands-down.<br /><br />This film takes the series back to the very beginning, when Bond is first granted his double-0 status. Based on Ian Fleming's novel, \\"Casino Royale\\" opens with a gritty black and white sequence that depicts Bond's first government-sanctioned kills. The film soon seeps into full-color mode and features a fantastic 20-minute footchase between Bond and a sprinty African bombmaker. Bond soon finds himself hot on the tails of Le Chiffre (Mads Mikkelsen), a terrorist banker who weeps tears of blood and has a nasty gambling habit that's lost his clients a lot of money. Le Chiffre decides to participate in a high-stakes French poker game in hopes of recouping his losses. MI6 sends Bond there to play against Le Chiffre and prevent him from winning. M (Judi Dench) sends a government accountant, Vesper Lynd (Eva Green), to keep an eye on Bond, but 007 can't manage to take his eyes off HER. Eventually Bond and Vesper find themselves in grave danger at the hands of Le Chiffre. There is torture, bloodshed, and suspense, but I don't want to give away any more of the plot because it's so exciting and I don't want to spoil it for anyone!<br /><br />Overall, \\"Casino Royale\\" is brilliant. Craig captures the true essence of James Bond that is depicted in Fleming's novels: an unstoppable killing machine. Craig's performance is also incredibly physical. (He did most of his own stunts for the film.) I really enjoyed the way that the film took a few steps back and attempted explain WHY Bond is the way he is (sort of the way in which \\"Batman Begins\\" reshaped the Batman franchise). This isn't the same suave and unfeeling Bond we all know and love. Craig's James Bond is much more human. He's very introspective and allows himself to fall in love with Vesper very easily. Ultimately, their romance doesn't have a happy ending, which explains why James is the way he is with women. So many pieces of the puzzle from more than 40 years of Bond movies fall into place because of this film.<br /><br />Daniel Craig, if you're reading this review, I'm so sorry that I ever doubted you! Now that I've seen the film, there is no doubt in my mind that you are TRULY James Bond! I still don't understand why the director didn't give you a box of Nice 'n Easy to darken up your hair a bit, but I got over the blonde thing after about ten minutes.<br /><br />James Bond is back, and he's better than ever! \\"Casino Royale\\" surpassed all my expectations. 0743298020|4.0|You absolutely must love the written word to appreciate The Thirteenth Tale. The old woman's hands were a \\"jumble of knuckles and rubies in her lap\\" - can you see it? Yes, the book wanders and meanders at times. It is reminiscent of novels from the nineteenth century, when mood was everything; when a reader had time to immerse him/herself in a pool of language and atmosphere and just float awhile.     I withheld a fifth star because, in my opinion, the ends were too neatly tied up, all the book-long agonies too quickly assuaged, all the wounds too successfully bandaged for the end to fulfill the promise spied in the first few chapters. But, to be fair, there really is no good way to end a good story.     Overall, I think I would describe Ms. Setterfield's style as equal parts Charlotte Bronte and Joyce Carol Oates, with a bit of Ruth Rendell in there for good measure. I anxiously await her next novel.

There's quite a bit of witty British dry jokes that are coming on and retro British songs from the olden years somehow fit into this movie brilliantly.  Unlike Diane Lane's Under the Tuscan Sun which is a bit forced, one word to describe this one is simply, \\"Charming\\".  Much criticism has been laid on Russell Crowes by critics and even viewers alike but personally, I think he's doing a wonderful job playing a character who has over the years lost his soul but inevitably redeeming it back in the end.  Overall, this movie is about love, life, friendship, wine, memory & Provence.  It would be appropriate to define this as Ridley Scott's homage or love letter to the land that he loves.  Once again, this movie proves the Director's versatility in tackling different genre.  A splendid movie with outstanding performances from all cast.  Highly recommended.

B0009A1AS2|5.0|I'll admit, I was rather late in picking this one up.  To be honest, I was a bit burnt on Dream Theater after _Train of Thought_ which is a fantastic, if sometimes exhausting, album.  (Sidenote: I also saw them on that tour and was there at the show where the guy fell out of the balcony.)  When I heard this was coming out, I held off for a long time, mainly because I had a backlog of albums to catch up on.  At the insistence of a friend, however, I checked it out and was very surprised (which seems to be a running theme) at what I heard.  <br /> <br />The album starts off well, with the Root of All Evil continuing what I've now deemed the Recovery Cycle (see also Glass Prison and This Dying Soul).  The song features one of my favorite chorus melodies in a long time.  The Answer Lies within is a quieter song that showcases the band's versatility.  It's probably the softest they've been since Scenes...  That's followed by These Walls, which picks up the tempo yet again before they go U2 on everyone with I Walk Beside You, a tune I like in spite of myself.  Panic Attack is the speedster of the album and proves that they haven't forgotten their metal side, as does Never Enough.  James Labrie gets the lyric credit for Sacrificed Sons, another religion-themed track that is less angry though more moving than TOT's In the Name of God.  Then, comes the best part of the show: Octavarium.  It shows everything that Dream Theater is about and more.  Portnoy's collaborations with Neal Morse shine through here, as Myung's bass really comes alive with a great, fat sound and Rudess's synths are warm and analog.  There's not much showmanship or many fireworks, but the song grows and builds from a quiet, Floydian exercise up to a huge crescendo that ends the album where it began.  The track alone is worth the price of admission. <br /> <br />One thing that struck me was the conciseness of the songs.  There are not as many technical fireworks, but it's still Dream Theater and the albumis stronger for it, making it an easier but no less interesting listen than previous records. Indeed, its subtleties are its strengths.  They have always been one of 'My Bands' and they proved why once again with this release.  Definitely one for the ages.

B000ICL3KG|2.0|Hopelessly misguided.  Overwhelmingly biographical.  Smartly directed. <br /> <br />Al Gore's never ending struggle to prove that mankind is destroying the earth and that the solution is international governmental control and primitive living reared its ugly head on the silver screen earlier this year and is now available on DVD!  Beware, though - that DVD is made of plastic, which is derived from a number of chemical compounds including - (gasp!) - oil.  The recipe for the movie, however, is 1 part science, 3 parts personal anecdotes, and 4 parts slideshow fun! <br /> <br />Mr. Gore has taken the liberty of inventing a scientific consensus (this is, of course after he invented the internet) on which to start his new campaign for president.  His movie is almost entirely about his own life.  A fair amount is devoted to his current struggle to advance the environmental movement, and what is left over is a small amount of very misleading science.  It isn't, necessarily, bad science - it is just far from representational.  However, I won't waste this review debating the scientific ideas advanced by Mr. Gore - there are plenty of other scientists and resources for that. <br /> <br />What needs to be recognized about this movie is that it is a campaign video and not an educational documentary.  There are components of informative dialogue and presentations, but this is really all about Al Gore, not global warming.  There is more discussion of how his political opponents have got in his way and in the way of his message than there is of actual solutions to the \\"problem.\\"  This is my big criticism.  The movie masquerades as a documentary to advance an environmental cause when it really intends to advance Al Gore's availability for political office.  Even in that light it still operates dishonestly. <br /> <br />Mr. Gore chastises the Bush administration for refusing to take action to stop global warming.  However, even when Gore was running the country with Bill Clinton, they did nothing.  In fact, Gore's proclamation in the movie that he tried diligently to get Kyoto passed but was stopped by the Republicans is bogus.  The Clinton administration found the protocol unworkable and challenged the fact that it only bound a few nations to action without timetables.  They never even submitted it to the Senate for ratification.  In this fashion, the movie continues with one dishonest claim after another. <br /> <br />In the end, the movie is full of misleading science and statistics, complete lies and fabrications, and it focuses more on the nobility of Gore than on any perceived global issue.  The only thing that makes me give it a second star is the fact that it was smartly directed and well edited.  The message that the movie intended to convey comes across loud and clear and with style - it's just not a message that anyone should hear or trust.

B00005JPCA|5.0|I don't know how general audiences will take to a re-imagined, back-to-the-source, colder and harder James Bond as brought to the screen by a thoroughly believable Daniel Craig, but for my money, the team behind Casino Royale has shot some juice back into what had become a lackluster, farcical, and moribund series, reinvigorating the characters while dispensing with much of the nonsense and clutter that had accumulated over the years.      I haven't gone to a theatre to see a James Bond movie in decades, the last memorable outing probably On Her Majesty's Secret Service (one of the better efforts: good movie, bad Bond (Lazenby).  I had seen the various Bonds over the years on cable or DVD and the movies were always somewhat amusing,  well-produced with some great stunts, but they had become so comic-booky and increasingly self-parodying that I found them hopelessly silly and overblown.  I found the Roger Moore era especially egregious and dismal while the attempt in the Timothy Dalton phase to sort-of get back to a grittier Bond was a nice try, but no cigar.  Pierce Brosnan's films were good, but by now so cluttered with nonsense that his last, with the invisible car and the villain's Ice Palace (nee Fortress of Solitude) only served to demonstrate that Bond had become Spiderman.    I had read with relish Ian Fleming's series as a kid and loved the first 3 or 4 Bond movies, with From Russia with Love and Goldfinger favorites, and closest to the novels.  Thunderball was okay, but I started to lose it with You Only Live Twice and the volcano fortress and rocket gobbling, Donald Pleasence doing Blofeld as Dr. Evil, and all the rest of the tripe they began piling onto the series.    So we come back to the first book in the series, Casino Royale, and the producers have shrewdly gambled on taking Bond Back to Basics.  I think they have succeeded admirably, and hope they will find an audience for the newer, harsher Bond.  Judging by some of the reviews from Bond loyalistsI read here, many of them also welcome a new breath of life in what was becoming a stale and outdated franchise.      You have terrific stunts with some really exceptional physical stunt work.  Fights that are nasty and brutal with pain that appears to be painful, and a double-O assassin who looks and acts like an assassin. Judy Dench is a marvelous M.  We have dispensed with Q and all the fantastical and silly gadgets for less but more appropriate equipment.  There aren't a bevy of Bond girls, but when you have the gorgeous Eva Green, you really don't need anyone else.  By and large the cliched quips are gone in favor of some dialogue that is actually kind of adult and often pretty snappy (thank you Paul Haggis).  You have villains that actually inhabit this planet and not Marvel Comics land.  There is a story with some twists and a beginning for Bond that lays the groundwork for some intriguing possibilities as to where they want to take him.  And you have Daniel Craig doing his damndest to re-define the role and make it his own.    Take away the Bond name and legacy, and you would still have a hell of a  good movie here.  It looks great.  It is richly produced with care, and is smartly directed.  It goes places Bond movies in later years seem to have feared to tread.  I enjoyed it immensely, and yes, I would pay to go see the next one in the theatre.  By bringing Bond back closer to Fleming's creation, and by bringing in an actor without the expected, traditional look but who is a bloody good actor, and by dispensing with great heaps of the rubbish, they've hooked me back into it.  I hope others find it as entertaining as I did.

1878424319|5.0|If you are seeking a thought-provoking bang for your personal-psychology buck, befriend this book.  <br /> <br />Ostensibly, the author attributes his inspiration for the four agreements to the Toltec, but the precepts work in most all cultural and temporal settings. <br /> <br />Practicing the simple insights shared in this book have had a profound impact on my life over the past two years since fervently reading the book aloud with a friend over the course of a night. Pulled along by the comparative explorations into personal styles, we stayed up all night and still carry the clarity with us. <br /> <br />Invariably, whenever I find myself in a torn or tormented situation, I can back-track to the root cause of my conflict being my violating one (or more) of these Four Agreements:  <br /> <br />1. Don't take things personally <br />2. Don't make assumptions <br />3. Always be impeccable with my word <br />4. Always do my best <br /> <br />In fact, straight-away after reading the book, my thornier issues wrestled mightily to deny the power of these perspectives, only later succumbing to their wisdoms. Most often, I found/find myself making an assumption and then taking it personally when the details fail to bolster my assumption. The worst case is when I am assuming that I am not making an assumption when I clearly am doing just that, like whenever I rant about being \\"right.\\" <br /> <br />I encourage you to read and reread this book. If you can, read or have it read to you aloud.  You are likely to learn a few things about yourself and about other people in your life. <br /> <br />The Four Agreements makes me think of Victor Frankl's small and very powerful book, Man's Search for Meaning, about the elements for surviving difficult times and finding happiness in life. Maybe the equation is that by living the four agreements, the meaning in a person's life emerges from the simple grace of those choices.

0618680004|4.0|After hearing an interview with Richard Dawkins on NPR, I decided to buy the God Delusion . The text is very engrossing, and I could not put it down--I read the entire book in a matter of days. As an Atheist, I found it to be an excellent summary for the case against religion, However, I must disagree with some of the other reviewers who said the text was groundbreaking or Earth shattering--as I read more on the subject I find that The God Delusion is mostly an updated version of existing arguments.<br /><br />For instance, in the chapter \\"Why There Almost Certainly Is No God,\\" -what Dawkins' calls the central argument of his book--he argues that while creationists believe that evolution is too improbable and that creation by deity solves this improbability, in actually there is an exponential level improbability added by supposing a deity, since we now have to answer the questions \\"who made God\\", and \\"who made who made God\\", and so forth. The same argument can be found in Bertrand Russell's \\"Why I am not a Christian\\" from 1927 (and Russell credits the idea to John Stuart Mill, from the latter's Autobiography), although not as scientifically postulated. Many of his other points, such as his counters of Aquinas' Proofs can also be found in the Russell text.<br /><br />From a stylistic point of view, it felt like it has been written as one long stream of consciousness dialog, with the reader following behind the easily distracted Dawkins. At times, this approach can be interesting, but other times it is very frustrating. I would have preferred him to stay more on point. The text as it stands may make it more approachable for casual readers, however.<br /><br />Overall, this is an excellent primer to modern secular beliefs, but I would encourage people who liked this book to continue reading other books on this topic. The Appendix and Works Cited in this book would be an excellent place to start.

I thought at least the Brotherhood version would have edited in some of the better or longer deleted scenes or maybe repositioned some of the various scenes, but there was absolutely no difference -- nothing!!!!  What idiot decided this was a good idea?  It was an absolute useless endeavor.  Given that I went out of my way to purchase the Region 1 version, I should have spent my money purchasing an Aussie version instead which includes more behind the scenes features and for basically the same price (or less0.  Shame on DVD producers for screwing the American Market - in hopes of reaping more gold by forcing them purchase the upgraded DVD (when it comes out) that will give the Region 1 market everything else the rest of the world already has (except Stan Lee's comic). For Shame!!!!
